Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 01:39PM tontoandme wrote:  Oh my I am sad to come here and read this as it doesn't sound good.  Lighting many candles for you Amy for the many women who love you very much and haven't spoken to you in a very long time.  You are in my thoughts, my heart, and my prayers. Me
Posts.Title: light a candle for lv2cmp (Amy) spar2 Marple

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2009 04:03PM tontoandme wrote: I am on Tykerb 5 pills/day and Xeloda 4,000 mg on 14 days of 7.  We started at a lower dosage and had to increase.  So far I feel really blessed as I am not having side effects like many do have.  Knock on wood - no hand and foot syndrome.  I get flu like symptoms and one darvocet seems to make me feel better.  My tumor markers went down too the last time.  I am hoping that it will continue to work because my next option would be IV chemo again.  Cheers for the Xeloda/Tykerb gals - may it work for all of us. Me
Posts.Title: Encouragement Offered respin heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2009 07:50AM tontoandme wrote: Just the other day my ONC told me that 10% of Stage 4 can be cured. He also told me that the longest one of his stage 4 patients lived under his care was 35 years!  That certainly gave me lots of Hope.
Posts.Title: Anyone 10 or 20 year surviror at this Stage TLF Padiddle

Posts.Content: tontoandme wrote: When I was born my parents named me Nicolette, I went to Catholic school so of course when I here that name my body still gets tense, it was those nuns in the good old days. Anyways many of you know me as I have been around since 2005 but then left for a very long time.  I was originally diagnosed stage 2, one node positive, er/pr negative, her2+.  Had bilateral mastectomy with reconstruction and my ovaries removed.  I was 55 y/o at the time of my diagnosis. Went through the whole 10 yards with dose dense chemo 4 rounds of A/C and 4 round of Taxotere.  3 months on Herceptin and had to stop because of heart problems. I actaully was doing pretty well and ready to celebrate my 4 years anniversary of NED.  Went for my usual 6 month oncology check up.  Even told the my ONC that I really thought I finally beat this thing.  I love pens from pharmaceutical companies and I remember that day I stole a Xeloda pen - just liked it cause it was big and easy to hold. 2 days later I get the call.  My tumor markers were up and that began my stage 4 journey.  Pet scans, MRI's.  My world all of a sudden became unside down.  I was told I have mets the day before my 59th birthday.  They made it sound so simple.  A small spot in your left hip and one intramammary node lit up. I had this terrible cough and pain on my side, thought is was a cold or a broken rib.  Chest x-ray showed pleural effusion.  Had a thoracentesis and they tool out over 600 cc of fluid.  It came back er/pr negative breast cancer mets.  So now I have pleural mets. My ONC started me on Xeloda (could kick myself for stealing that pen) and Tykerb.  All in all I have done well on it with very little side effects, well side effects are managed by Darvocet, but thats ok.  Each month my tumor markers went up especially the CEA and each month they increased my Xeloda.  I'm on 4,000 mg/day. I had a CT scan this past Saturday of the chest, the abdomen, and the pelvis.  My pleural effusion is back only it's bigger.  The mets are still there in my left femur.  But my relief was that the cancer had not spread to anymore places at least for now.  My ONC took more tumor markers and if they went up I was facing IV chemo once again. So today I got the results.  My CA15-3 went up a little and the CEA went up a little, but I got a little reprieve.  He said stay on the Xeloda for another month. I know so many of you and you can pm me if you haven't figured out who I am.  My heart was broken just like so many when you first hear you have mets.  I realized today I am getting used to this and it will be part of my life.  I'm a fighter, always have been and even though some days I get discouraged, I try to look at things different because well things are different now. I am not a troll, this is real life and it's hard.  I used dots all the time and I don't review my posts so I'm sure there are always words not spelled correctly.  I usually blame that on me being left handed.... I need to come here and be with others who are stage 4.  I have so many good friends, but it's just hard if you know what I mean.  While they are on diets to lose weight to be healthy, I keep eating cheese cake and chocolate because...well I can. Just taking sometime to say hello to you and talk a little. Me  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Just taking time to talk tontoandme pip57

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2009 06:32AM tontoandme wrote: I missed the whole context of this thread.  I came here this morning after losing one of my furbabies and wanted to have a good laugh.  Something to clear the fog from my brain.  So many of you had dealt so well with your diagnosis of Stage 4 - sometimes I am embarrassed at how much selp pity I seem to have everyday.  I fear the frown on my face will become permanent.  Still fairly new with mets and trying to get through the everyday disappointments.  The feeling that I will never get good news again.  Being someone who worries about spilling salt or walking under a ladder I somehow correlate my mood with my progress. If I have had a difficult month I fear my tumor markers will go up.  Yet if I have had a good month my tumor markers will go down.  Silliness, I know.  I stopped laughing the day I was diagnosed with mets, doom and gloom has surrounded me for 7 months now.  As I watched the video of that baby laughing, I found myself laughing out loud - it felt good. I really don't have any comments on the laughing yoga talk, but I know that I want to take my head from under the covers and laugh a little.  Not for a cure, but to make that day, that moment a little easier to cope with. So Blue, thanks for that video and to all of you who are going through this horrific stage 4 journey I send love and thanks, because although I don't post much you have given me much support while I am trying to figure out who I am now. Me
Posts.Title: Laugh and love your cancer back to health. Laughjoyfully CapeBretongirl

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 07:04AM tontoandme wrote: I got my regualr flu shot yesterday, but I don't plan on getting the H1N1 flu shot.  It concerns me that they haven't had enough time to make it and I wonder about it's safety.  Also heard that it has mercury in it.  me
Posts.Title: H1N1 Poll--ALL STAGES WELCOME! badboob67 wildgardener

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2009 05:02AM - edited Oct 23, 2009 05:06AM by tontoandme Up early like usual and just waiting for my coffee to finish brewing.  I must say I am realy enjoying meeting so many of you.  I feel a little sad because I can see I am losing touch with a whole group of ladies I have been friends with for years now.  But I can tell by their words they don't know what to say to me as I am the only stage 4 in the group.  So it's nice meeting and talking to new people.  I wish it were Saturday. It's one of those days where it's raining and would feel great just to crawl back into bed.  I hate when it rains like this as my job involves me driving around and walking outside lot from place to place.  And I can't even say I am thankful for the rain so it will bring flowers.  I have to remind myself it is Fall and Winter will be here soon. I mentioned my husband and others acting differently.  I think what is the hardest for me is my husband because he is going through a serious depression through this whole thing that I am dealing with.  People keep telling me this is about you, but it's hard to watch someone you love having difficulty coping and for the life of me I have such a hard time trying to help him get through this.  Heck, I am having a hard enough time helping myself. The wine yesterday was wonderful.  I had a glass while I was here and another with dinner which was perfect because DH made an Italian dish and the Merlot went perfect with it.  I was thinking that my ONC is pretty smart giving me a month reprieve from the IV chemo.  He knows me well enough that I wouldn't handle that easy...more like kicking and shouting the whole way.  So do you all have ports?  I'm not looking forward to getting one again, but I was glad I had a port during my last chemo. Also wondering what kinds of things do you like to do?  I have become isolated as my home feels so safe.  So basically I go to work and stay at home.  Being with groups of people makes me very nervous.  I love to take walks and just look around to appreciate mother nature.  And as I am walking I think of so many things, talk to the animals and love to tell stories. Kathy:  My gosh being a preschool teacher sounds hard, but on the other hand lots of fun.  Nothing more precious than being around the innocence of a child.  Good that you have 2 days that you can recup and regenerate.  My job is flexible in that I can leave early if I need to.  I have so much paperwork and can do that at home.  So that does help lots.  It's fast paced which I have always enjoyed, I evaluated 20 people yesterday and 5 diferent hospitals.  My biggest fear now is being exposed to all these infections that are going around.  If I catch a cold it tends to go to pneumonia now, so I am very careful.  I did get the regular old flu shot yesterday but I don't know if I like this swine flu shot.  Haven't made up my mind if I will get it or not. mthomp:  Glad the Navelbane is being kind to you.  Do you get hair loss with it?  I didn't wear a wig last time and if I go on this IV chemo I won't wear a wig this time either.  Going to go out and buy lots of hats and earrings, but gosh darn my it took 4 years for my hair to get it's thickness back.  I have been known to open a bottle of wine and before I know it somehow it's empty.  The good old days.  I love Martini's, my favorite being a dirty Martini with a little olive juice and two olives in the glass.  Of course if I drank one now it would knock me on my butt.  You are right as I am not a good support group person.  I find coming here is much more therapeutic for me. Last night I had some chocolate covered almonds from a gourmet shop.  A treat indeed, but I ate way too many.  No wonder I can't lose weight.  Someone mentioned living in Chicago and I think my eyes are stlll sleepy because I can't find that post.  I too live in the Chicago area. Live in one of the Western suburbs and my job is to drive around Chi town all day.  Hope you all have a wonderful Friday and that some sunshine fills your heart with warmth. Me
Posts.Title: Just taking time to talk tontoandme pip57

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2009 07:11AM tontoandme wrote: Zeeka:  Yes we have all been brought together because of breast cancer, but I too sometimes just want to talk, laugh at something or get my mind off what is happening.  There are many threads here at bco to do that, but never before have I seen in the Stage 4 Forum and lately that is where I seem to hang out.  So my story for the day is very simple.  I am trying to lose some weight, but I do remember getting up last night and eating a twinkie and a Carmel ice cream drum stick.  Covered with chocolate and nuts and carmel filling.  And this morning I have no guilt.  Loved ever bit of it. And this morning I am going to have pancakes. So there!  The diet can wait another week-end. Me
Posts.Title: get together on this zeeka71 allalone

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 04:35AM tontoandme wrote: Elizabeth you made me laugh about trying to get your car to pee in a cup.  I don't think I could get mine to.  We have talked lots and I am happy for you moving back to Canada althought moving in December seems like quite a project.  Cold, cold, cold.  I started pulling out my newsboy caps from the last time and actually wore one to work yesterday.  Thought it would be a good idea to get people used to the look.  Funny thing is even before cancer, I was a hat person. Me
Posts.Title: Just taking time to talk tontoandme pip57

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 06:23PM tontoandme wrote: Amy, you will be dearly missed.  I am glad I had the opportunity to meet you.  My condolences to all family and friends who are going through such a difficult time right now.  Me
Posts.Title: AMES (lv2cmp) RIP -angel- heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 04:47AM - edited Oct 22, 2009 04:52AM by tontoandme Well some of you will get to know that I am an early riser.  I'm still working full time while on chemo and that gives me very little if any computer time.   I had made friends with many stage 4 sisters prior to my diagnosis and I was always amazed and the strength anf fortitude you all had.  Couldn't understand how you got through each day and thought each day in itself must be a nightmare.  Now I understand and although working on chemo is hard, it gets my mind off things and that part is good.  I think if I didn't work I would just lie around in bed all day - not good! I woke up today in good spirits.  I start my 14 day Xeloda cycle today and can't believe I am actually looking forward to taking it.  All of a sudden it doesn't seem so bad after coming inches away from IV chemo.  I always say this is my time, the early morning hours.  House is quiet, no interruptions and I can enjoy my morning coffee. Diane I was so happy to see a post from you.  I have been lurking for along time and wondered where you were.  Then wonder turned to worry.  It's nice talking to you again.  We certainly did have our conversations and if I remember correctly we were able to laugh lots despite what we were going through.  Angel thanks for the hugs.  I feel it is I who should be sending out hugs to all of you.  As I read your stories you all will never know how motivating you have been to me.  I didn't take the news well in the beginning and someone here always made be feeel better. Livestrong:  Yep despite the nuns trying to change me, I am left handed. I was a fighter then too lol.  I'm feeling happy today a good way to start the day.  Hope all goes well with your husband next week.  Hate all those darn tests and the fear that goes along wit hit. Lisa:  Hope I didn't make a mystery out of myself.  I know the gals that have been on here from way back when and I am starting to get to know the newer gals.  Yep, I think this part of the journey stinks but I also am finding something good in each day and thats how I get by. Kelly I wish I could send back hugs to everyone of you.  Some of you are further in this stage 4 journey than I am and I want to reach out and say everything will be ok. Hattie:  The thing that brought me back is that I see what you mean.  We are all in this together.  When I am having a crappy panic day, I need to tell someone.  Yet on the otherhand when things are going well I want to share it.  Kathy:  I started a caringbridge too.  And I am amazed at the amount of people who come there everyday to lend me support and a helping hand.  But there I am quite self centered and only talk about myself.  Being here I get to talk to others and friendships build as we go along.  I think the one thing that was really hard for me was that all of a sudden I felt like I was in a postion where I coulnd't help people anymore.  But I know being here I can help others just like I need help.  When I first started Xeloda I was so scared because I read how many had terrible side effects.  It has worked out very well for me.  It's almost like a baby blanket that I don't want to give up. Jeannie:  The constant up's and down's are so amazing to me and I never know when I will be up or down.  I was in a big meeting with the owners of where I work and got the phone call while I was presenting my report.  And the dang phone rang loudly playing girls just want to have fun.  I look at all the managers and the owner and said I HAVE to take this call.  Then afterwards had to clear my head and go back into the meeting looking professional.  Pftttt on that.  I never thougth in a million years I would be looking forward to taking chemo, yet this morning I can't wait to have breakfast so I can start my Xeloda again. Elizabeth, yes I am who you think I am and I have missed you lots.  I have been coming here to read everyday just to see what is going on and glad I finally had the nerve to come back.  I am into pies now.  Pumpkin pie is sounding really good right about now. Thanks for all your replies, it going to be nice to get to know all of you again.  Hoping you all have a wonderful day and that at least something touches your heart that makes you smile. Me
Posts.Title: Just taking time to talk tontoandme pip57

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2009 04:35AM tontoandme wrote: I want to color my hair so bad but it is thinning from my chemo and I am afraid the chemicals will make it thin more.  I look 10 years older.  I even bought a rinse and then chickened out as I have never colored my hair myself, I always have gone to a hair salon. I think coloring my hair would help me get out of this darkness I feel now that I'm stage 4. Me
Posts.Title: Hair Dye ??? alancer tontoandme

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2009 05:06AM tontoandme wrote: Dear nancy, I am so sorry you have been put in this situation, I know how overwhelmed you feel because that is how I felt when I was told about my mets.  And then to be faced with making a decision regarding adoption - which in itself is stressful, although wonderful. I don't believe any of us know how much time we have left, but I read here and see many women surviving and living their lives with multiple mets.  And living longer than I would have ever imagined.  Coming here has giving me so much hope when my darkest thoughts tell my I have a poor prognosis.  Has your onc put you on a new treatment plan?  I think when it comes to adoption, taking care of a baby is a full time job and I wonder with treatment will you be able to do both.  Be a mother and heal yourself.  Sometimes it seems like this cancer likes to knock us down right when we are feeling positive and ready to enjoy life, and I hate that this has happened to you. It's hard enough struggling with the news but to have to make a decision regarding adoption seems mind boggling to me.  Know that there are many of us here who will try and help you through this very hard time.
Posts.Title: Absolutely overwhelmed nancyh saint

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2009 03:59PM tontoandme wrote: Well I must admit I have learned a few thing in the past few days.  The most important thing was that it seems many of you drink wine.  I haven't had a glass of wine in so long, so today I bought myself a botttle and I am savoring a glass of Ecco Domani merlot.  It definitely was worth the wait. I don't have much china but a friend gave me some really pretty wine glasses so I pulled one out. Since we were talking about food, chocolate especially I gave in on my way to work and got a chocolate bagel with chocolate cream cheese.  Whew the calories, but it sure tasted good.  I have to say I had a really good day, I am lucky that my work is flexible and everyone was so concerned about the IV chemo thing.  ONC didn't want to increase my Xeloda he was afraid it would become too toxic so I'm hoping this stuff kicks in.  As usual we can only hope. So I was wondering, since you have been diagnosed stage 4 are you finding people are treating you different?  My hsuband has definitely changed his attitude.  Seems to be pulling away like he is getting ready to lose me or something - heck I plan on being around for along time. River:  Hit to you, I'm not a legend...just got to know lots of people here.  In my early days I was sort of a person who had her big panties on and they still were too tight.  Always was invovled in some controversial thread and thought I knew everything and was right about everything.  I have certainly be humbled since then. I think I learned my stubborness from being a nurse and working in ICU.  Always had to hold my fist up to some of those doctors.  I am very gald to meet you and hope to get to know you better. MomoB:  Thanks for your kind words.  One year ago I never thought I would be here, but as time goes by I am getting used to it.  And of course the glass of Merlot is a perfect way to end my day. Janis:  Interesting combination Herceptin and Zometa.  If I go on IV chemo it will be Abraxane, Zometa and Carboplatin.  Not sure if Tykerb fits in the picture but I sure hope it does, otherwise I'm thinking herceptin again too.  I'm also wondering about Avastin.  My biggest problem is I know too much and do too much research.  I can't imagine you working full time and taking care of your young children.  That has to be hard. Me, I come home and take care of myself - well except for my dog and cat. Hope you all have a good evening,  It's raining here and the temperatures dropped.  A typical fall day in the Midwest. Me
Posts.Title: Just taking time to talk tontoandme pip57

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2009 09:00AM - edited Sep 19, 2009 09:01AM by tontoandme I too have pleural mets.  I cough all the time.  Sometimes it is dry, sometimes there is mucous, and when the fluid starts to collect in my lung I get lots of pain.  I have inhalers to use for the wheezing.  I carry sugar free toffee flavored life savers and when the dry cough starts, the life saver helps.  I am very frustrated with this new diagnosis.  It all seems so scary to me.
Posts.Title: paroxysms of coughing Analemma tontoandme

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2009 01:18PM tontoandme wrote: Maybe it's time to just go aunatural!  I look like my mother did. me
